results.title: Warrior women
results.creator_credit: Christine Gillespie, Generation Films, Jacqui Ward, Michael Buckley and Sue Smith
results.brief_description:
The Warrior Women CDROM and booklet evolved out of the Warrior Women Exhibiiton. Warrior Women is a moving, insightful and innovative mixed media art exhibiiton created by women exploring their experiences of breast cancer. Women of all ages, cultural and social backgrounds collaborated with women artists to develop this significant exhibition. The collaborations took place over a two year period and resulted in over 100 pieces of art including videos, projections, audio, slides, photographs, digital designs and writing.

The Australia Council for the Arts funded the redevelopment of the Warrior Women Exhibition artworks into a booklet and an interactive CDROM. These were distributed throughout Australia by the Breast Cancer Network, Australia.

results.title: Warp and weft
results.creator_credit: Betty Brunke, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Weaving, one of man’s oldest arts, still offers pleasure and opportunity for self-expression to both beginner and expert. We watch a class of weavers, under expert guidance, “dress” their looms and weave the useful and attractive articles of their choice, a delicate evening scarf, fabric for a suit, or the practical table mats woven by a beginner. The process of weaving is seen in close-up and slow motion. Traditional Scottish and European designs are shown with excellent contemporary work from every part of Canada, indicating the popularity of the craft today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Betty Brunke, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Warner in the wild
results.creator_credit: David Gray, Wendy Campbell and Greenway Films
results.brief_description: Follows the band “Dave Warner From the Suburbs” as it tours around the far northwest of Australia, suffering the heat and hardships of such a trip. Incorporates some of Warner’s most popular songs as well as providing comments by Warner as to the content of his lyrics, which portray suburban living and the Australian character, as no other Australian songwriter has done. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Warming up
results.brief_description: The intense atmosphere generated by members of an orchestra in the last five minutes before going on stage. The film makes an analogy between the mechanics of the human body and that of the musical instruments, the instruments seem equally alive as their players - only the performance they are about to share matters.

results.title: Warm nights on a slow moving train
results.creator_credit: Bob Ellis, Patric Juillet, Ross Dimsey and Western Pacific Films
results.brief_description: Wendy Hughes plays an art teacher employed at a Catholic girls’ convent school from Monday to Friday. At weekends she rides the overnight express train between Sydney and Melbourne as a prostitute in order to keep her addict brother supplied with morphine. Every week she changes her appearance, mannerisms, and personality, luring male clients who always pay and leave by 3 a.m. However, an intelligence agent (Colin Friels) becomes her lover and they team up to murder a politician on the train. Wendy Hughes exudes sensuality, power and passion in the lead role.

results.title: Warkamu (A)
results.creator_credit: Ian G Wallis, Monash University and Abschol Organisation
results.brief_description: Studies an Aboriginal community, south of Port Hedland, Western Australia, which supports itself by mining alluvial tin and tantalite-columbite deposits.

results.title: Wardens of Waterton
results.creator_credit: Leslie McFarlane and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Every summer thousands of visitors come to Waterton Lakes National Park to enjoy its mountain grandeur, fishing, swimming, and all the other attractions that make for summer enjoyment. To show how this heritage of beauty and pleasure is preserved year after year, the film takes us on a tour of large-scale outdoor housekeeping. We see not only how wardens organise and administer the Park’s services, but also how they protect wildlife and co-operate with their partners across the border, the rangers of Montana’s Glacier Park.

results.title: War, tears and memories
results.creator_credit: Jean Parry and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jean’s greatest memory was the Battle of Alemein. She remembers the noise and the booming of the guns and the flood of patients needing attention. Serving as a army nurse during World War II, Jean recalls some of her most memorable times during the war, as well as her life in Melbourne, growing up with four brothers in Oakleigh and how 17 members of her family attended the Anzac Day march in 2009.

results.title: War, man's destiny
results.brief_description:
Combines art work, original drawings, and excerpts from classical European paintings in an animated film which recreates the blood contests between the French and Russians in the Napoleonic Wars, and which deplores the horror of war in all times and places. Set with music from Tchaikovsky’s 1812 Overture.
(Awards: Special Jury Prize, Cannes, 1973)

results.title: War without winners
results.creator_credit: Haskell Wexler, Harrold Willens and Center for Defense Information
results.brief_description: In 1979, in cooperation with the Members of Congress for Peace Through Law Education Fund, the Center for Defense Information financed this short documentary to promote the unilateral disarmament lobby’s claim that, “there is no defense against nuclear war,” on which basis they also oppose civil defense programs, anti-ballistic missile defenses and development of satellite-based beam weapons. Combines footage of nuclear tests, presidential speeches and interviews with military leaders with opinions expressed by Russian and American members of the public. Includes President Eisenhower, Jimmy Carter, retired US Navy Admiral La Rocque, former CIA Deputy Director Herbert Scoville and Civil Defense consultant William Kincade. Also includes historical footage of nuclear bomb blast tests in the US desert. Narrated by Paul Newman.
